of 1890, with areas excavated superimposed Tables 1 Archive quantification 2 Finds quantification 3 Pottery, summary by context 4 Charred plant remains, assessment results 5 Charred plant remains, contexts assessed Birmingham Archaeology ii Longdales Road Archaeological Excavation 2006 SUMMARY The third in a series of archaeological excavations was undertaken at Longdales Road, Kings Norton, Birmingham (centred on NGR. SP 05337761), in August-September 2006. This report describes the results of the most recent fieldwork and provides proposals to being the results to publication. The fieldwork was undertaken by Birmingham Archaeology on instruction from Birmingham City Council, and was undertaken in advance of a cemetery development. The excavation followed an initial archaeological evaluation in 2002 which identified remains of possible field boundaries and a pebble surface adjoining Icknield Street. Earlier archaeological excavation elsewhere within the cemetery development excavated a triple ditched enclosure, probably used for the corralling of livestock. A second focus of activity was located by excavation in 2003-4, also to the rear of the Icknield Street frontage, comprising ditched enclosure boundaries, cobbled surfaces, pits and post-holes. The pottery dating indicates that the site was in use from the 2nd to the early 4th century. Two areas were excavated in 2006, one immediately adjoining the Icknield Street road frontage. The earliest activity probably comprised the layout of ditched plot boundaries at right-angles to the Roman road. The full width of three plots (A-C), and part of a fourth plot (D) were recorded within the area investigated. The plot boundaries were further defined by metalled roads adjoining the ditched boundaries. The excavated part of the Plot A road frontage comprised a metalled surface, possibly used as a hardstanding for storage, which was not continued along the frontage area of the other excavated plots to the north. Plot B contained a rectangular ditched enclosure within which was sited part of ring-gully. Plot C also contained a ring-gully, which may have been in use in late Phase 1-early Phase 2. Phase 2 activity was in general more limited. The main Phase 2 feature was the northeastern angle of a ditched enclosure, cut through the two Phase 1 road surfaces in Plot A. This enclosure was associated with an east-west aligned ditch. Further to the north the only Phase 2 feature was a large pit. With the exception of the Phase 1 Plot B enclosure, activity was concentrated away from the road frontage, most notably in Phase 2. The pottery from Phase 1 contexts was dated mainly in the second half of the 2nd-3rd century. This material included Severn Valley ware jars and bowls, a Malvernian tubby cooking pot, and Black Burnished ware. Phase 2 activity was dated to the late 3rd-4th century. It included Severn Valley jars and tankards, and mortaria from Oxfordshire and Mancetter Hartshill. Birmingham Archaeology iii Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 LONGDALES ROAD, KINGS NORTON, BIRMINGHAM ARCHAEOLOGICAL EXCAVATION 2006 POST-EXCAVATION ASSESSMENT 1 INTRODUCTION 1.1 Background to the project This report describes the results of a third archaeological excavation at Longdales Road, Kings Norton, Birmingham, undertaken during August-September 2006 (centred on NGR. SP 05337761; Area B, Fig. 1). Birmingham Archaeology was commissioned to undertake the archaeological excavation by Birmingham City Council, which was undertaken in accordance with the guidelines laid down in Planning Policy Guidance Note 16 (PPG16, Department of the Environment, November 1990). The archaeological fieldwork was undertaken in advance of proposals for a cemetery extension. This report provides a post-excavation assessment of the results of the 2006 fieldwork, prepared in accordance with the Management of Archaeology Projects 2 (MAP 2 - English Heritage). The fieldwork was undertaken in accordance with a Design Brief prepared by the Council (Birmingham CC 2006), and a Written Scheme of Investigation prepared by Birmingham Archaeology (Birmingham Archaeology 2006), approved by the Planning Archaeologist, Birmingham City Council, and following the requirements of the Council's Archaeology Strategy, adopted as Supplementary Planning Guidance. The site (Fig. 2) of the proposed cemetery is bounded by Longdales Road, Icknield Street and Primrose Hill. The land is currently overgrown pasture, with the exception of those areas presently laid out as a cemetery. The proposed development site is bounded by Icknield Street to the east, which follows the line of a Roman road. Just outside the site boundary is Lilycroft Farm, thought to be of medieval origin and mentioned in a document of 13th century date. The farm is a Grade II listed building, including fabric of late 17th and early 18th century date. Early stages of work comprised a desk-based assessment, walkover survey, and trial-trenching carried out by Worcestershire County Council Archaeological Service (Vaughan 2002) in March 2002. The trial trenching involved machine-cut trenches in Fields 1-2 and 4, which revealed ditches, shallow gullies and some pits/post holes. These features were interpreted as a forming a Romano-British settlement focus, consisting of an enclosure complex to the west of Lilycroft Farm, with an associated ditched field system to the north. Birmingham Archaeology 1 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 Preliminary fieldwork by Birmingham Archaeology in 2002 (Williams 2003a) included further trial trenching in Field 1, close to Icknield Street, to determine the extent of activity in this roadside zone, revealing ditches, pits and cobbled surfaces. Following further trial trenching in Field 1, an excavation (Area A) was undertaken in the southwest of the proposed cemetery site, to investigate a Romano-British enclosure complex which was occupied from the 2nd to the 4th century AD. The sequence of Romano-British activity was divided into three phases. The earliest activity (Phase 1) consisted of three small ditches and a series of pits, largely concentrated in the south of the area excavated. Phase 2 comprised the majority of the features, including the outermost two enclosure ditches, as well as a ring gully and areas of stone surfacing. The latest Romano-British activity was formed by an inner enclosure ditch and an internal, rectangular stock enclosure, cut in Phase 3, possibly during a reduction in site activity. The trial-trenching and Area A excavation results are described in a post-excavation assessment (Williams 2003a), and the associated detailed specialist reports, site narrative and illustrations have been prepared(Williams Evans and Burrows forthcoming). The 2003 excavation (Area B), located to the west of the area investigated in 2006 revealed the remains of a Romano-British settlement dating from the 2nd-4th century AD, represented by three phases of activity (Williams 2003b). The earliest phase of activity (Phase 1) consisted of a single enclosure ditch or field boundary, with smaller ditches and gullies dug outside the enclosed area. In Phase 2 two possible enclosure ditches were cut in the north of the area investigated; a further ditch, gully and pit were also contemporary. Also belonging to this phase were a number of structural remains, including beam-slots, cobbled surfaces, a ring gully and four post pads, possibly representing the remains of a large timber building with associated cobbled surfaces. One of the cobbled surfaces was covered in an ashy deposit containing the charred remains of spelt and glume, indicating the possibility of malting and beer production. The latest Romano-British phase (Phase 3) was represented by two ditches and a large pit. Little evidence of post-Romano-British activity (Phase 4) was recorded. A watching brief was maintained in 2004 during groundworks associated with the construction of the main cemetery roads, and associated drainage works (Mason 2004) within Fields 1, 2 and 4. A number of ditched plot boundaries were identified, together with post-holes and a ring-gully in the west of Field 1 (Mason 2004, fig. 3). The purpose of the present report is to describe the results of the 2006 excavation (Areas C-D), to assess the finds and environmental evidence from that excavation, and Birmingham Archaeology 2 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 to provide proposals for an integrated publication of the 2002-3 and 2006 excavations in a recognised archaeological journal. 1.2 Aims The general aims of the 2006 excavation (Area C-D) were to identify archaeological remains, and to preserve those remains by record. The specific aims were to reveal, excavate and interpret any features associated with the occupation of the western frontage of Icknield Street, and the area to the rear of the road frontage, where evidence of plot or field boundaries may be anticipated. 2 METHODOLOGY The 2006 fieldwork was undertaken in two stages. In Stage 1 two trenches, each measuring 50m by 2m were excavated, positioned at an oblique angle to the main areas for excavation, and between them. Stage 2 comprised the investigation of the two main areas (C and D) selected for investigation, following completion of work in the two trenches. Within the excavated area the overburden was removed by a mechanical excavator working under archaeological supervision to expose the uppermost horizon of the natural subsoil. A base plan was prepared, from which the detailed strategy for sampling by hand-excavation was devised. Within 60% of the excavated area sampling by hand- excavation comprised half of each discrete feature, and 20-50% of linear features associated with settlement. This sampling strategy was applied to the western of the two areas investigated (Area D). Within the roadside area, where the feature density was less intense, a single excavated slot was dug through each feature identified, and discrete features were half-sectioned. As an exception, the eaves-drip gully was sampled by means of several hand-dug segments. Further investigation of the eaves-drip gully has been agreed, but is postponed due to bad weather. Recording was by means of a continuously numbered sequence of cut and context numbers. During the excavation, pre-printed pro-formas for contexts and cuts were completed, together with digitally-surveyed plans (1:50) and hand-drawn sections (1:20 and 1:10). Monochrome and colour slide photographs were also taken. Subject to permission from the landowner, it is proposed to deposit the finds and paper archive with the Department of Human History, Birmingham Museums and Art Gallery. Birmingham Archaeology 3 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 3 RESULTS 3.1 Phasing The results from the 2006 excavation have been provisionally divided into two phases of Romano-British activity, based on spot-dating of the pottery and the recorded stratigraphy. Phase 1 Early Romano-British activity, late 2nd-early 3rd century Phase 2 Later Romano-British activity, later 3rd-4th century The Romano-British archaeological features were all cut into the natural subsoil, uncovered at a depth of between 0.3-0.45m below the modern ground surface. Those excavated features which were merely changes in the natural geology, modern plough furrows or field drains are not described below. Most of the features were attributed to Phase 1. The Phase 1 features were cut into the natural red-brown clay subsoil (6004/7002). 3.2 Phase 1 The main features excavated were a series of ditched plot boundaries cut on an east- west alignment, at a right-angle to Icknield Street. Some of the plot boundaries were further defined by metalled roads adjoining the ditched boundaries. Within the areas excavated were examined an area close to the roadside frontage (Area C), and an area to the rear of the frontage (Area D), close to the area investigated in 2003 (Area B). Many, but not all of the east-west aligned ditched boundaries could be traced within Areas C and D, in some cases because of differential preservation. The plots extended over 100m to the rear of the Icknield Street frontage, assuming that the Roman road was roughly contiguous with the modern road. Within Areas C and D were investigated the full width of three plots (lettered A, B and C, from south to north), and part of a fourth (D). Plot A measured approximately 28m in width (measured centre to centre of the road surfaces). Plot B to the north measured 31m in width, and Plot C measured 22m in width. Finally, Plot D was recorded for a maximum width of 14m, but its northern limit was not recorded within the excavated area. Plot A The southern boundary of Plot A was formed by a pebble road surface, 6147, measuring up to 4m in width. Towards the Roman road frontage the road joined an east-west Birmingham Archaeology 4 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 aligned pebble surface, 6147A, recorded for a maximum width of 5.5m, and for a length of 21m. The only features recorded within Plot A were two adjoining pits, 6091 and 6095, each measuring an average of 0.65m in diameter, located to the rear of the frontage, and single post-hole, 7033, recorded closer to the Roman road frontage. The features were backfilled with brown-grey silt-sand-clay. The western continuation of road 6147 may have been located in Area B excavated in 2003 (F442, Williams 2003b, fig. 2), and during the watching brief in 2004 (F119, Mason 2004, fig. 2). Plot B The northern limit of Plot A and the southern boundary of Plot B were defined by an east- west aligned metalled road, 6074, and a parallel ditch to the north, D1. The alignment of the southern edge of this road varied between Areas C and D, possibly as a result of resurfacing on a slightly different alignment. The road was better preserved in Area D, being more truncated, perhaps as a result of ploughing, in the Roman roadside area. This metalled surface was composed of pebbles measuring 0.02-0.10m in diameter with occasional slightly larger sub-rounded stones. The road measured between 3.0 and 3.8m in width and survived to a depth of between 0.04 and 0.09m in depth. A single post-hole, 7048, was cut into the road surface in Area C. In contrast to the road surface, the associated ditch, D1, was better preserved towards the road frontage area, D1a. The ditch segments cut in Areas C and D followed slightly different alignments; the alignment recorded towards the road frontage, D1a, being tangential to ditch D1. Overall, the ditch was cut to a U-shaped profile, and measured an average of 0.8m in depth, and between 0.16m and 0.26m in depth. It was backfilled with orange-brown sand-silt. Within the excavated part of Plot B was recorded the eastern and western ends of a rectangular enclosure, Enclosure E1, dug to the north of roadside ditch D1. Parts of the northern, D6, the western, D5, and eastern, D4, sides of the enclosure were recorded within the areas excavated. As so defined, the enclosure measured 22m (north-south), by a maximum of 50m (east-west). The eastern side of the enclosure was misaligned with the other sides of the enclosure, and with the Plot B boundaries. The westernenclosure ditch, D5, was cut to the north of roadside ditch D1/D1a. No relationship could be observed between the enclosure and roadside ditches, which may have respected each other. D5 was cut to a U-shaped profile, and measured a maximum Birmingham Archaeology 5 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 of 0.7m in width, and 0.32m in depth. The western edge of the ditch was cut by a post- hole, 6113, which measured 0.3m in diameter. An entry-gap measuring 0.7m in width was retained at the northwestern angle of the enclosure. The entry-gap was further defined by a north-south aligned gully, 6136, cut flush with the western terminal of the northern ditch of the enclosure, D6, and by a pit, 6134, cutting D5 towards its northern terminal. The pit measured 0.98m in diameter. D6 was cut to a U-shaped profile, and measured an average of 0.35m in depth, varying from 0.5m to 0.8m in width, at its western and eastern terminals, respectively. The eastern ditch of the enclosure, D4 measured an average of 0.43m in depth, and between 0.8m and 0.52m in width, at its northern and southern terminals, respectively. The southern terminal of D4 respected D1a, the northern roadside ditch. Within the Enclosure E1 interior, the main group of features were concentrated within its southeastern angle, and comprised a circular ring-gully, R2, and associated features. The earliest features of this group were two post-holes, 7062 and 7064, which were both cut by ring-gully R2. The eastern half of the ring-gully was recorded within the excavated area. R2 measured 8.2m in diameter. It measured 0.4-0.5m in width, and 0.15m in depth, and was cut to a U-shaped profile. It was backfilled with charcoal-rich sand-silt- clay, 7025. An oval, east-west aligned oval hearth, 7017, was recorded within R2. 7017 was backfilled with grey-brown silt-sand-clay, 7016, flecked with charcoal. A single post- hole, 7060, was recorded within the interior of R2. To the south of R1 was a line of small stones, 7074, which may represent the base of a truncated gully, surviving to a depth of only 0.02m. This feature could possibly represent the eastwards continuation of D1, although this could not be proven. Also to the east of R2 was a pit, 7046, measuring 1.2m in diameter, and cut to a U-shaped profile. Ditch D5 was backfilled with light grey-brown silt-clay. D6 and D4 were backfilled with light grey silt-sand-clay. Few features were located within Plot B outside the enclosure. A single post-hole, 7033, was recorded immediately to the east of Enclosure E1. It measured 0.4m in diameter. Further to the southeast was a further single post-hole, 7039. To the west of the enclosure was a spread of stones, 6069/6103, curvilinear in plan, and recorded for a length of 10m. This feature may represent the base of a heavily truncated ditch or gully. This adjoined a single post-hole, 6115. Other possible features tested by hand- excavation were proved to be of natural origin. Birmingham Archaeology 6 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 The northern Plot A and southern Plot B ditched boundary may have been continued to the west, into Area B (F419, Williams 2003b, fig. 2). Plot C The northern boundary of Plot B and the southern boundary of Plot C was formed by an east-west aligned metalled surface, 6109, with a ditch to its northern edge, D2, similar to the arrangement recorded on the Plot A/B boundary further to the south. Surface 6109 measured a maximum of 5m in width, and comprised small sub-rounded pebbles. Two post-holes, 6011 and 6015, were cut into the surface. The post-holes averaged 0.6m in diameter and 0.18m in depth. Ditch D2 was heavily truncated by a post-medieval field boundary, 6123/7054, dug following the Roman alignment. The main feature identified within the interior of Plot C was a ring-gully, R1, possibly oval in plan. The southeastern half of the feature was recorded; the remainder, perhaps originally less substantial in depth, having been removed by truncation. R1 measured 10.3m in diameter. An entry-gap, measuring 0.6m in width was recorded in the southeastern angle of the feature. The ring-gully was cut to a U-shaped profile. It measured a maximum of 0.6m in width and 0.18m in depth (in the southeast), to 0.26m in width and 0.05m in depth along its southwestern side. R1 was backfilled with grey- brown silt-sand-clay. A number of features were recorded within the interior of R1. Three post-holes, 6071, 6076 and 6078, in the southwest of the ring-gully could have been associated with an entrance structure not otherwise surviving. An adjoining pit, 6119, was also recorded. Traces of stone-packing survived within 6071, which was cut to a U-shaped profile, and measured 0.38m in diameter, and 0.18m in depth. Two further post-holes, 6080 and 6082, and a small pit, 6087, were recorded towards the centre of the ring-gully. The post-holes measured an average of 0.35m in diameter, and 0.18m in depth. The central group of features could have represented central supports to the structure. R1 and the associated features could have been in use in late Phase 1, or early Phase 2, as suggested by the pottery dating evidence. The only other feature within Plot C was a large, flat-based pit, 6017, recorded to the southwest of R1. In plan, it measured 6.4m by 5.8m, and was cut to a maximum depth of 0.26m. It was backfilled with redeposited subsoil and light grey silt-clay, 6016. The sequence of backfills suggests gradual backfilling of the feature, which is interpreted as Birmingham Archaeology 7 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 an animal watering hole. The feature was surrounded by a possible pebble surface (not illustrated). No features were recorded in this plot closer to the Roman road. The northern Plot B/ southern Plot C boundary may have been continued to the west, into Area B (F410, Williams 2003b, fig. 2). Plot D The northern limit of Plot C, and the southern side of Plot D was defined by an east-west aligned ditch, D3, and a metalled road, 6146, recorded immediately to the north. D3 was cut to a U-shaped profile, and measured 0.5-0.65m in width, and 0.1-0.23m in depth. In Area D the ditch became notably less substantial in the east of the excavated area, which might suggest its possible eastward continuation into Area C, adjoining the roadside area, could have been entirely scoured-out by truncation. D3 was backfilled with brown sand-clay. In contrast to the other ditched plot boundaries, ditch D3 was slightly curvilinear in plan. This irregularity might suggest that it was not part of the original Roman layout. This hypothesis is supported by the narrow width of Plot C (22m), compared with a width of approximately 30m for Plots A and B, although admittedly it is not possible to draw firm conclusions from the limited sample of the roadside area provided by the 2006 excavation. The small excavated sample of the Plot D interior contained no identifiable Roman features. The absence of features within the interior of this plot is not surprising given that more of the plot's interior was tested towards the Roman road frontage, which contained few features in Plots A-C to the south. The southern Plot C/ northern Plot D boundary may have been continued to the west, into Area B (F408, Williams 2003b, fig. 2). A further ditched boundary (F405), cut on the same alignment in Area B was not recorded as continuing into Area C. A stone surface (F421) was found in Area B to the south of plot boundary ditch F410. This stone surface could be equivalent to surface 6109 found in Area C. Dating evidence Enclosure E1 contained pottery dating to the 2nd-3rd century, AD 120+, late 2nd century +, and to the 2nd-3rd century from ditch D5, and to the 2nd-3rd century from ditch D4. Ditches D1 and D2 contained Roman pottery. Ditch D3 contained pottery dating AD 120+, to the mid 2nd-early 3rd century, and to the 2nd-3rd century, as well as material classed only as Roman. Road surface 6074 contained pottery dating to the 2nd-4th century. Pit 6017 in Plot C contained 2nd century pottery. Birmingham Archaeology 8 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 3.3 Phase 2 The metalled roads, 6147 and 6074, defining the southern and northern limits of Phase 1 Plot A had gone out of use by the end of Phase 1. It is not clear if the other parallel roads and plot boundaries had gone out of use at the same time. The main Phase 2 feature was the northeastern angle of a ditched enclosure, Enclosure E2. Only part of the eastern side, and a very short length of the northern side of this enclosure were recorded at excavation; its other sides lay outside the excavated area. The eastern ditch of the enclosure, D7, was cut through Phase 1 roads 6147 and 6074, and the northern ditch, D8, was also cut into surface 6074. The eastern ditch, D7, was cut to a U-shaped profile, and measured between 0.8-1m in width, and 0.36m-0.5m in depth. It was backfilled with grey silt-sand-clay. The short excavated length of the northern ditch, D8, was cut to a similar profile, and measured a maximum of 1.58m in width and 0.5m in depth. It was backfilled with mid grey-brown silt-sand-clay, 6072. An east-west aligned ditch, D9, cut to the north of Enclosure E2 may have been associated. D9 was cut for a distance of 20m. Ditch D9 was cut through the backfilled Phase 1 ditch D5 (Enclosure E1) and into the subsoil, 6004. Ditch D9 was cut to a U- shaped profile, and measured a maximum of 0.63m in width, and 0.15m in depth. It was backfilled with grey-brown silt-sand-clay. This ditch may possibly represent a re- definition of the Phase 1 northern Plot A, and southern Plot B boundary ditch D1. A gap measuring 4m was retained between ditch D9 and the northern side of Enclosure E2, D8. This gap could suggest that part of the width of Phase 1 road 6074 could have continued in use during Phase 2, a suggestion which may be supported by the recovery of pottery dating to the 2nd-4th centuries from its surface. Further to the north was a pit, 6062, sub-circular in plan, measuring a maximum of 2.5m in width, and 0.5m in depth. It was backfilled with charcoal-flecked silt-clay. In the extreme northeastern angle of Area C was an irregular pebble spread, 7076, which sealed the backfilled Phase 1 plot boundary, D3. As noted above, R1 in Phase 1 Plot C could also have continued in use into Phase 2. The northeastern side of Phase 2 Enclosure E2, D8, was approximately flush with the northern terminals of ditches F416 and F417 (Williams 2003b, fig. 2), which might suggest that they represented the northern end of the western side of this enclosure. Assuming that this interpretation was correct, an entry-gap would have been retained at Birmingham Archaeology 9 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 the northwestern angle of the enclosure, since no trace of the western end of its northern side was recorded within Area B. The maintenance of an entry-gap at the corner of an enclosure is an arrangement often associated with the sorting of livestock. Dating evidence Ditch D7 contained pottery dating AD 240+ and residual material dating AD 120+; of 2nd to 3rd century date, and of 3rd to 4th century date, and residual material of late 2nd to 3rd century date from the same cut. Ditch D8 contained pottery of late 3rd to 4th century date. Ring-gully R1 contained pottery dating AD 240+, and associated feature 6082 contained pottery dating to the 3rd-4th century which may suggest the features continued in use into Phase 2. Finally, pit 6062 contained pottery dating to the 3rd-4th century. 4 ASSESSMENT 4.1 Quantifications TABLE 1: Archive quantification (excludes 2002 evaluation) Record Number Contexts/ features 280 Assemblage summaries 1 file Colour slide 3 films Colour print 2 films Black and white prints 3 films Drawings 80 Env sample record files 1 Survey file 1 Birmingham Archaeology 10 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 TABLE 2: Finds quantification (excludes 2002 evaluation) Material type Quantity Fired clay/daub 8 Romano-British coarse pottery 430 Samian 4 Mortaria 1 Post-medieval pottery 9 Post-medieval iron objects 5 Slag 13 Post-medieval coin 1 4.2 Small finds None of the recovered finds, with the exception of the pottery, was worthy of assessment or detailed study. 4.3 Pottery by Jane Evans The 2006 fieldwork at Longdales Road produced 435 sherds of Romano-British pottery, weighing 3.3kg. Sherds were heavily abraded, due to the acidic soils. Most context groups were very fragmentary, though some contexts produced more substantial fragments (for example a near complete profile of a tankard from 6062, f 6065). The assemblage came from 48 stratified contexts, only 13 sherds being unstratified. The assemblage is summarised and spot dated in Table 3 below. However, two broad phases of activity were apparent. Evidence for 2nd century activity (Phase 1) is provided by a Malvernian tubby cooking pot (cf Peacock 1967, fig. 1.1, 2). A number of Severn Valley ware forms date broadly to the 2nd to 3rd centuries: Webster type A6 and C22 jars (Webster 1976, fig.1, fig. 4 respectively) from D5/6105, f 6104; D4/7022, f 7021; 6017, f 6016. Some Severn Valley ware bowls (from layer 6074; 6085, f 6084) dated more specifically to the late 2nd to 3rd centuries (Webster 1976 type F50, fig. 8). A Black Burnished ware, grooved rim bowl or dish (layer 6024) also indicates activity some time around the mid 2nd to early 3rd century (Seager Smith and Davies 1993, fig. 123, type 24). It is possible that these latter forms provide a more reliable indication of the earliest activity on the site. A few sherds of samian were also recovered, all very abraded. These have not been identified and need to be examined by a specialist. It is possible, based on the evidence from previous excavations at Longdales Road (Willis 2003) that these date to the Antonine period. A fluorit of activity during the second half of the 2nd century would be consistent with the evidence from the 2003 excavations (Evans 2005). A variety of forms dated to the late 3rd or 4th century (Phase 2). The Severn Valley ware included a Webster type C27 jar (Webster 1976, fig. 5) and a splayed tankard (Webster 1976 fig. 7, type E43 or E44), from D8/6073, f 6072 and 6062, f 6065, respectively. Black burnished ware flange rimmed bowls (Seagar Smith and Davies 1993, fig. 124, type 124) from R1/6082, f 6081; and D7/6085, f 6083 also provided good evidence for this period of activity, as did Oxfordshire mortaria (Young 2000, fig. 21 M18 and fig. 22 M20) from R1/6029, f 6028 and D7/6047, f 6050. A rim from a Mancetter Hartshill, multi-reeded hammerhead mortarium could be contemporary (context 6096). Late 3rd to 4th century activity is also attested at the previously excavated Longdales Road sites (Hancocks 2003; Evans 2005). Some contexts were given a tpq of c AD 120, based on the presence of body sherds in Black Burnished ware. It is likely that these in fact date to at least the mid-to-late 2nd century, based on the BB1 forms identified. Other contexts provided no diagnostic fabrics and forms and could only be broadly dated to the Roman period. Birmingham Archaeology 13 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 Sources The range of sources is similar to that noted in previous excavations at Longdales Road. The assemblage is dominated by Severn Valley ware, representing more than 70% by sherd count. Other sources included Dorset Black Burnished ware and Malvernian ware, and mortaria from Mancetter Hartsh and the Oxfordshire kilns. Only 4 sherds of samian were recovered, fragmentary body sherds and a base, all badly abraded. No amphorae was present. Recommendations The assemblage complements the evidence from previous excavations at Longdales Road (Hancocks 2003; Evans 2005) and needs to be fully recorded for publication. It is estimated that c 25 sherds w require illustration. The material from the 2002 evaluation w be integrated with the material from the 2006 excavation. 4.4 Charred plant remains by Val Fryer Introduction and method statement Samples for the retrieval of the plant macrofossil assemblages were taken from across the excavated areas, and twenty two were submitted for assessment. The samples were bulk floated by Birmingham Archaeology and the flots were collected in a 500 micron mesh sieve. The dried flots were scanned under a binocular microscope at magnifications up to x 16 and the plant macrofossils and other remains noted are listed on Tables 4 and 5. Nomenclature within the tables follows Stace (1997). All plant remains were charred. Modern contaminants including fibrous roots, seeds, fungal sclerotia and arthropods were present throughout. Results With the exception of charcoal fragments, plant macrofossils were exceedingly scarce. Single grains of barley (Hordeum sp.) and wheat (Triticum sp.) were recorded along with a spelt wheat (T. spelta) glume base and individual seeds of persicaria (Persicaria maculosa/lapathifolia) and dock (Rumex sp.). Preservation was quite poor, with most remains being puffed and distorted (possibly as a result of combustion at very high Birmingham Archaeology 14 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 temperatures) and very fragmented. As noted above, charcoal/charred wood fragments, including some very large pieces, were present at varying densities throughout although again, preservation was poor, with much of the material being heavily abraded. Other plant macrofossils were all but absent, although minute pieces of charred root/stem were recorded within three assemblages. Other material types were also very scarce, and it is considered most likely that of those recorded, most were intrusive within the contexts. Many of the porous and tarry residues had the appearance of modern `coke' and small coal fragments were also recorded. Conclusions and recommendations for further work Without exception, the assemblages are all extremely small (most being considerably 0.1 litres in volume) and most contain little other than charcoal/charred wood fragments. There is no evidence for the primary deposition of material within any of the features recorded, and it would appear most likely that the assemblages are largely derived from scattered or wind-blown hearth waste, which accidentally became incorporated within the feature fills. It is not clear whether this may imply that the site was little used and peripheral to any main centre of activity or whether it was kept clear of most refuse. The poor condition of the material may indicate that it was either exposed for a considerable period prior to burial, or it has become abraded as result of the subsequent disturbance of the deposits (as possibly suggested by the modern contaminants). As none of the assemblages are quantifiably viable (i.e. containing 100 specimens), no further analysis is recommended. Context Cut Feature type/construct Contents 4 6028 6029 Ring gully R1 CH;BTM;COAL 10 6016 6015 Ring gully R1 CH;CR/ST;BTM;COAL 20 6072 6073 Ditch D8 CH;BPC;BTM 23 6079 6080 Post hole CH;BPC;COAL 25 6086 6087 Pit CH 26 6100 6101 Ditch D5 CH 28 6096 6097 Ditch D5 CH 29 6112 6113 Post hole CH;BPC 30 6118 6119 Pit CH;BPC;COAL 34 7025 7026 Ring gully R2 CH 36 7021 7022 Ditch D4 CH 38 6129 6130 Road CH 40 6131 6132 Ditch D6 CH 41 6135 6136 Gully CH 42 6133 6134 Pit CH Key to Tables x = 1 ­ 10 specimens xx = 10 ­ 50 specimens xxx = 50 ­ 100 specimens xxxx = 100+ specimens cf = compare CH = charcoal BTM = black tarry material CR/ST = charred root/stem BPC = black porous `cokey' material 5 UPDATED PROJECT DESIGN 5.1 General This section of the assessment defines the main research themes. Most of the research themes identified in the previous assessments (Williams 2003a and 2003b) remain relevant. Chronology For the purposes of assessment, the Roman features have been divided into two phases. Phase 1 represents the first definition of the plot boundaries, also associated with Enclosure E1 in Plot B. This phase is dated to the later 2nd-early 3rd century. Ring-gully R1 in Plot C may also be attributed to this phase, although its later re-cutting and re-use is suggested by the recovery of 3rd-4th century pottery from the fill. Phase 2 activity is dated to the later 3rd-4th century. Only limited activity is recorded in this phase, Birmingham Archaeology 17 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 comprising the cutting of a ditched enclosure (Enclosure E2) across Phase 1 Plot A, the excavation of a pit, 6062, and the layout of a stone surface, 7076, close to the Roman road frontage. The evidence from Areas C and D suggests that the floruit of this Roman activity was during the later 2nd-early 3rd century. In contrast, activity in the adjoining Area B (Williams 2003b) was more intense during the later 3rd-4th century. Further analysis of the pottery from Areas C and D, and comparison with the material from Area B, and the features found in that area w further refine the sequence and dating, as well as facilitating comparison with the Area A evidence. It has been suggested above that the different width of Plot C, and the slightly curvilinear plot boundary, D3, could suggest that this plot was not part of the original layout, although this cannot be proven. Area B ring-gully F411 (Williams 2003b) was cut by plot boundary F410, which may have defined part of the Plot B/C boundary, suggesting that activity away from the road frontage pre-dated the formal layout of plot boundaries which extended up to the Roman road frontage. Site function and morphology: changes The earliest Roman activity within Areas C and D was the layout of plot boundaries, defined by ditches, metalled roads or both. The limited dating evidence suggests that this layout dates to the later 2nd century. With the exception of Plot B, few internal features could be identified. Plot B contained a rectangular enclosure, Enclosure E1, one side adjoining the southern ditched boundary of the plot. The enclosure contained a ring-gully and a number of associated features, mainly post-holes. An entry-gap was recorded in the northwestern angle of the enclosure, which suggests use of the enclosure for livestock. A broad, flat-based pit, 6017 located in Plot C may be interpreted as an animal drinking trough. Although not exactly the same in width, the similarity in the width of the excavated plots A and B could suggest that they were laid out as one operation. An intriguing possibility is that plot boundaries were laid out along the eastern and western frontages of the Roman road at the same time. Ordnance survey mapping (Fig. 4) indicates that the Plot A/B and C/D boundaries were approximately flush with existing field boundaries recorded on the eastern frontage of Icknield Street. The southern boundary of Field 1 is also likely to have been cut on the line of a Roman plot boundary; the distance between the field boundary and the southern Plot A boundary was similar to the average plot boundary width recorded. Moreover, Field 4 to the south is approximately three such plot boundaries in width. Remaining on the western side of the Roman road, there are three field boundaries which run at a right-angle to it recorded to the north of Longdales Road (Fig. 4). Fieldwork by Worcestershire CC has identified a Birmingham Archaeology 18 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 pebble surface to the east of Lilycroft Farm, and a continuation of Roman activity to the south of Primrose Hill. Phase 2 activity in Areas C and D was more limited in extent than that of the preceding phase. With the exception of metalled surface 7076 no Phase 2 activity was recorded close to the road frontage. This metalled surface clearly implies that the Plot C/D boundary had gone out of use in this phase. Phase 2 Enclosure E2 could have been associated with livestock, particularly if it was associated with the possible northwestern side of the enclosure containing an entry-gap, as recorded in Area B (F416, F417, Williams 2003b). Site economy and function Investigation of the Area C and D roadside areas is complimentary to the previous areas investigated (Areas A and B). In each case an association with animal husbandry may be suggested. Investigation of Areas C and D confirms that the site was not a `typical' roadside settlement, in which case a concentration of features would be anticipated immediately adjoining the Roman road. The results of the 2006 excavations suggest that the occupation of the frontage area was not domestic in nature, with the sole exception of ring-gully R2. Most significantly, the plot boundaries were recorded for a distance of at least 90m to the rear of the Icknield Street frontage. Such a plot depth is unlikely to be associated with domestic occupation, since roadside plots are typically no more than approximately 30m in depth. Comparison of the pottery w help to elucidate site status and trading patterns, as well as any intra-site variations. Site function and status Excavation in 2006 has demonstrated that the roadside area was not the main focus of activity. Rather, settlement was concentrated to the rear of the frontage, and the road frontage area was also given up in the later 3rd century. The morphology of the Area A enclosure complex (Williams 2003a) suggests an association with livestock. Evidence from excavations in 2002, 2003, 2004 and 2006 suggests that the settlement remains were not confined to a single farm. It is possible that the remains could have formed part of a small hamlet (Hingley 1989, 76) where multiple `compounds' would be anticipated. The economy of the site may have been dependant on livestock, rather than the opportunities provided to sell goods or produce to travellers. One possibility is that the site was a local market centre (Hingley 1989, 112), perhaps with a particular emphasis Birmingham Archaeology 19 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 on the sale of livestock. The position of the Longdales Road settlement within the local hierarchy of settlement should be explored in detail. Roman, and post-Roman landscape archaeology The identification of different settlement foci (Area A, Area B, and Area C/D roadside activity) provides some opportunities for landscape reconstruction, and also for comparison with other extensively-investigated Roman roadside settlements (e.g. M6 Toll, A5 Weeford-Fazeley, A1(M) Ermine Street, Cambridgeshire, A419/A417, Wiltshire/Gloucestershire, among others). Evidence for the post-Roman landscape should also be considered. 5.2 List of updated aims 1) To define the chronology of the enclosures and other Romano-British features. 2) To provide an understanding of the changes in site morphology and function. 3) To attempt to define the site economy and function, including a review of the comparative evidence. 4) To relate the site to the hierarchy of later Roman rural settlements in the midlands and in the surrounding region. 5) To attempt to reconstruct the Roman roadside landscape, and to provide comparison with other Roman roadside excavations focusing on the corralling of livestock. 6 PUBLICATION SYNOPSIS The results w be fully integrated with the results from the previous excavation and published as a monograph in a recognised archaeological journal (eg BAR). It is intended to publish the results of work in Areas A-D as sequential sections within a single overall report, within the following overall arrangement Chapter 1 Summary and introduction (Areas A-D and watching brief Chapter 2 Area A Description and interpretation of results Finds Discussion Chapter 3 Area B Description and interpretation of results Birmingham Archaeology 20 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 Finds and environmental evidence Discussion Chapter 4 Areas C-D Description and interpretation of evidence Finds and environmental evidence Discussion Chapter 4 Summary of watching brief Chapter 5 Synthesis and overview The suggested layout of the Area C-D section of the overall report is as follows: Text Summary (250w) Introduction, aims and methodology, archaeological setting (with Areas A-B, 1000w, 2 figures) Description and interpretation of results (4,000w, 1 table, 5 figures, 5 plates) Finds and environmental evidence Roman pottery (3,000w, 2 tables, 1 figure) Charred plant remains (1,000w, 1 table) Discussion (3,000w) Contribution to general discussion and synthesis (1,000w) Total 13,250 w, 4 tables, 5 plates, 8 figures Figures 1 Site location 2 Site location, topography and alignment of Roman road 3 Areas investigated (A-D) 4 Simplified plan, Phase 1-2 features 5 Detailed plans of ring-gullies 6 Phase 1 plan 7 Phase 1 sections 8 Phase 2 plan 9 Phase 2 sections 10 Pottery Birmingham Archaeology 21 Longdales Road: Archaeological Evaluation 2005 (Overall site plans w include details of features found by Worcestershire CC fieldwork) 8 TASK LIST STAGE A, PRELIMINARY ANALYSIS.
